cases.name: R (on the application of Begum) (Respondent) v Secretary of State for the Home Department (Appellant) [2021] UKSC 7
cases.summary:
Facts
• Shamima Begum was a British citizen who left the UK to join ISIS in Syria.
• In 2019, the Home Secretary revoked her citizenship on the basis that she was a security threat to the UK.
• Begum challenged this decision in court, arguing that it made her stateless and that she could not effectively challenge it from Syria.
• The Court of Appeal found that the decision was unlawful because it rendered Begum stateless and because she would not be able to have a fair and effective appeal against it.

Issues
• The main issues in the case were whether the Home Secretary's decision to revoke Begum's citizenship was lawful, and whether it breached her right to a fair and effective appeal.
• The Home Secretary argued that the decision was taken in the interests of national security, and that Begum was not rendered stateless because she was entitled to Bangladeshi citizenship through her parents.
• Begum argued that she was effectively stateless because she had never been to Bangladesh and did not have any connection to the country.
• She also argued that she could not effectively challenge the decision from Syria, where she was living in a refugee camp without access to legal representation or evidence.

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the Home Secretary's appeal against the Court of Appeal's decision.
• The Court found that the decision to revoke Begum's citizenship did not breach her right to a fair and effective appeal because she could pursue her case from Syria with the assistance of lawyers and that the decision did not render her stateless as she could claim Bangladeshi citizenship.

Key passage(s)
• 'the right to a fair hearing does not trump all other considerations, such as the safety of the public. If a vital public interest makes it impossible for a case to be fairly heard then the courts cannot ordinarily hear it. The appropriate response to the problem in the present case is for the deprivation appeal to be stayed until Ms Begum is in a position to play an effective part in it without the safety of the public being compromised.' (Lord Reed, paragraph 50)

cases.name: R (on the application of Miller) (Appellant) v The Prime Minister (Respondent) [2019] UKSC 41
cases.summary:
Facts
• Following the referendum vote to leave the European Union (EU) in 2016, the UK government triggered Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union, beginning the process of leaving the EU.
• The Prime Minister, Boris Johnson, advised the Queen to prorogue (suspend) Parliament for five weeks, claiming it was necessary to prepare a new legislative agenda.
• However, the suspension was challenged by Gina Miller, who argued that it was an unlawful abuse of power by the Prime Minister to prevent parliamentary scrutiny of Brexit.

Issues
• The central issue in this case was whether the advice given by the Prime Minister to the Queen to prorogue Parliament was justiciable (capable of being reviewed by the courts) and, if so, whether it was lawful.
• Miller argued that the Prime Minister's advice was unlawful because it had the effect of frustrating or preventing the constitutional role of Parliament in holding the government to account.

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously held that the Prime Minister's advice to prorogue Parliament was unlawful because it had the effect of frustrating or preventing the constitutional role of Parliament without reasonable justification.
• The prorogation was therefore void and of no effect.
• The Court also held that the advice was justiciable, meaning that the courts have the power to review it.

Key passage(s)
• 'The Prime Minister's advice to Her Majesty was unlawful, void and of no effect. This means that the Order in Council to which it led was also unlawful, void and of no effect and should be quashed. This means that when the Royal Commissioners walked into the House of Lords it was as if they walked in with a blank sheet of paper. The prorogation was also void and of no effect. Parliament has not been prorogued' (Lady Hale).
• 'The longer that Parliament stands prorogued, the greater the risk that responsible government may be replaced by unaccountable government: the antithesis of the democratic model' (Lady Hale).

cases.name: R (on the application of Privacy International) (Appellant) v Investigatory Powers Tribunal and others (Respondents) [2019] UKSC 22
cases.summary:
Facts
• Privacy International, a human rights organization, brought a claim against the Investigatory Powers Tribunal (IPT) and other defendants, challenging the lawfulness of the regime for the interception and use of communications data under the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000 (RIPA).
• The IPT is a judicial body responsible for hearing complaints against the intelligence services.
• Privacy International argued that the IPT's decisions were not subject to adequate judicial scrutiny and that RIPA was incompatible with EU law.

Issues
• The main issue was whether RIPA provided an adequate legal framework for the interception and use of communications data, and whether the IPT's decisions were subject to adequate judicial scrutiny.
• Privacy International argued that the regime was incompatible with EU law and violated the right to privacy, while the defendants argued that the regime was necessary for national security and subject to sufficient safeguards.

Decision
• The Supreme Court held that RIPA was incompatible with EU law because it did not provide for an independent body to authorize the interception of communications data, and because it did not require prior review by a court or independent administrative body.
• The Court also held that the IPT did not provide adequate judicial scrutiny of the intelligence services' activities, as it did not have the power to quash decisions or provide effective remedies for violations of human rights.
• However, the Court declined to make a formal declaration of incompatibility, as the relevant provisions had already been replaced by the Investigatory Powers Act 2016.

Key passage(s)
• 'The IPT is not a true court … [it] does not have the power to quash decisions or provide effective remedies for violations of human rights' (Lord Carnwath)
• 'The 2000 Act did not lay down clear and precise rules providing for access to and use of communications data … the access and use of that data was not limited to what was strictly necessary' (Lady Hale)

cases.name: R (on the application of Bancoult No 3) (Appellant) v Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs (Respondent) [2018] UKSC 3
cases.summary:
Facts
• The Chagossian Islanders were forcibly removed from the Chagos Archipelago by the UK government in the late 1960s and early 1970s in order to make way for a US military base. The UK government declared the Chagos Archipelago a British Indian Ocean Territory (BIOT) in 1965.
• The appellant, Bancoult, a Chagossian, sought judicial review of the UK government's decision not to allow Chagossians to resettle in the BIOT.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the decision made by the UK government not to allow resettlement was lawful.
• Bancoult argued that the decision was unlawful because it was based on a flawed consultation process and was in breach of the European Convention on Human Rights.
• The Secretary of State argued that the decision was lawful and that the European Convention on Human Rights did not apply to the BIOT.

Decision
• The Supreme Court dismissed Bancoult's appeal.
• The Court held that the decision not to allow resettlement was lawful and that the European Convention on Human Rights did not apply to the BIOT.
• The Court found that the consultation process was flawed, but that this did not render the decision unlawful.

Key passage(s)
• 'The concept of a 'colony' is a relic of the past. The manner in which the Chagossians were removed from the Chagos Archipelago, and the appalling conditions in which they were thereafter forced to live, are a stain on the history of our country. Nevertheless, as a matter of law, the actions of the executive and the legislature, in relation to the designation and governance of the BIOT, cannot be impugned' (Lord Mance, para. 1).
• 'The European Convention on Human Rights does not apply to acts or omissions of the Crown in relation to the BIOT or any other overseas territory, except to the extent provided by orders made under section 2(2) of the Human Rights Act 1998' (Lord Mance, para. 65).

cases.name: R (on the application of UNISON) (Appellant) v Lord Chancellor (Respondent) [2017] UKSC 51
cases.summary:
Facts
• The case of R (on the application of UNISON) (Appellant) v Lord Chancellor (Respondent) [2017] UKSC 51 involved a challenge to the lawfulness of employment tribunal fees introduced in 2013.
• The fees, which ranged from £390 to £1200, were required to be paid by claimants in order to bring a claim before an employment tribunal.
• UNISON argued that the fees hindered access to justice and were discriminatory against women and other protected groups.

Issues
• The main issue in the case was whether the employment tribunal fees were unlawful and discriminatory.
• UNISON argued that the fees were a violation of the principle of access to justice, as they prevented workers from enforcing their employment rights.
• The Lord Chancellor argued that the fees were necessary to reduce the burden on taxpayers and to deter frivolous claims.

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously held that the employment tribunal fees were unlawful and discriminatory.
• The court found that the fees had prevented access to justice and discriminated against women, as they were more likely to bring low-value claims that were disproportionately affected by the fees.
• The court also found that the fees were not reasonably necessary to achieve the stated policy goals of reducing the burden on taxpayers and deterring frivolous claims.

Key passage(s)
• 'The constitutional right of access to the courts is inherent in the rule of law. The importance of the rule of law is not always understood. Indications of a lack of understanding include the assumption that the administration of justice is merely a public service like any other, that courts and tribunals are providers of services to the “users” who appear before them, and that the provision of those services is of value only to the users themselves and to those who are remunerated for their participation in the proceedings. The extent to which that viewpoint has gained currency in recent times is apparent from the consultation papers and reports discussed earlier. It sometimes seems as though Lord Woolf’s reforms, which were designed to enable the courts to serve the people better, have turned into a mechanism for the management of the justice system in the interests of the efficiency of the courts rather than in the interests of the people for whose benefit the courts exist.' (para. 64, Lord Reed)

cases.name: R (on the application of Miller and another) (Respondents) v Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union (Appellant) [2017] UKSC 5
cases.summary:
Facts
• This case concerned the legality of the UK government triggering Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union, which would begin the process of leaving the EU.
• The claimants argued that the government could not trigger Article 50 without an Act of Parliament.
• The government argued that it had the power to trigger Article 50 under the royal prerogative.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the government had the power to trigger Article 50 without an Act of Parliament.
• The claimants argued that triggering Article 50 would result in a change in domestic law and therefore required parliamentary approval.
• The government argued that the royal prerogative allowed it to make and unmake treaties without the need for parliamentary approval.

Decision
• The Supreme Court ruled in favour of the claimants, stating that an Act of Parliament was required before the government could trigger Article 50.
• The court held that triggering Article 50 would result in a change in domestic law, and that the royal prerogative could not be used to change domestic law.
• The court also held that the European Communities Act 1972, which gave effect to EU law in the UK, could not be repealed without an Act of Parliament.

Key passage(s)
• 'The change in the law required to implement the referendum's outcome must be made in the only way permitted by the UK constitution, namely by legislation' - Lord Neuberger (para. 26)
• 'The 1972 Act provides that rights enjoyed by UK residents by virtue of the UK's membership of the EU were created by a source of law which also forms part of UK law. Hence, withdrawal from the EU would remove some existing domestic rights of UK residents, and the government cannot lawfully remove rights granted by Parliament unless Parliament permits it to do so' - Lord Clarke (para. 114)

cases.name: R v Jogee (Appellant) [2016] UKSC 8
cases.summary:
Facts
• In R v Jogee (Appellant) [2016] UKSC 8, two men, Jogee and Ruddock, were convicted of murder after they burgled a house and Ruddock fatally stabbed the homeowner.
• The trial judge instructed the jury that if they found that Jogee was a party to the crime, he would be guilty of murder as well.
• This was based on the doctrine of joint enterprise, which holds that if two or more people are jointly involved in a crime, they are all equally responsible for any foreseeable consequences, including murder.

Issues
• The central issue in the case was whether the doctrine of joint enterprise had been applied too widely.
• Jogee argued that the law had been misinterpreted and that he should not have been convicted of murder simply on the basis of his involvement in the burglary.
• The prosecution argued that the doctrine was an important tool for holding criminals accountable and should not be abolished or restricted.

Decision
• The UK Supreme Court ruled that the doctrine of joint enterprise had been wrongly interpreted by the courts for over 30 years.
• They held that the doctrine had been applied too widely and that it was not enough to simply prove that someone was involved in a crime in order to convict them of murder.
• Instead, the prosecution needed to prove that the defendant had intended to commit murder or had foreseen that murder was a possible consequence of their actions.
• The court also held that the doctrine should not be abolished entirely, as it played an important role in certain cases.

Key passage(s)
• 'The law took a wrong turn in 1984 when the Privy Council decided in Chan Wing-Siu that foresight of consequences was sufficient to establish the necessary intent for secondary liability in murder.' (Lord Neuberger, para. 20)
• 'In our judgment, the correct interpretation of the law is that a person who assists or encourages another to commit a crime is criminally liable for any acts committed in the course of that crime which are a natural and foreseeable consequence of what was agreed between them.' (Lord Hughes, para. 95)

cases.name: Montgomery (Appellant) v Lanarkshire Health Board (Respondent) (Scotland) [2015] UKSC 11
cases.summary:
Facts
• Nadine Montgomery has diabetes and was pregnant with her son during 1999.
• Her son was born with severe disabilities after a difficult delivery.
• Montgomery claimed that the doctors did not inform her of the risk of shoulder dystocia, which is a condition where the baby’s shoulder gets stuck during delivery. This condition is more likely to occur in women with diabetes.

Issues
• The key issue was whether the doctors had a duty to disclose the risk of shoulder dystocia to Montgomery.
• The doctors argued that they had acted in accordance with their usual practice, which did not include informing patients of the risk of shoulder dystocia.
• They also argued that a warning would have led to Montgomery requesting a caesarean section, which would have been riskier for her and her baby.

Decision
• The Supreme Court held that the doctors had a duty to disclose the risk of shoulder dystocia to Montgomery.
• The court stated that doctors have a duty to take reasonable care to ensure that patients are aware of any material risks involved in any recommended treatment, and of any reasonable alternative or variant treatments.
• The court also held that the doctor's usual practice was not enough to discharge their duty to provide Montgomery with the information she needed to make an informed decision about her treatment.
• The court found that Montgomery would have chosen to have a caesarean section if she had been informed of the risks.

Key passage(s)
• 'An adult person of sound mind is entitled to decide which, if any, of the available forms of treatment to undergo, and her consent must be obtained before treatment interfering with her bodily integrity is undertaken. The doctor is therefore under a duty to take reasonable care to ensure that the patient is aware of any material risks involved in any recommended treatment, and of any reasonable alternative or variant treatments. The test of materiality is whether, in the circumstances of the particular case, a reasonable person in the patient's position would be likely to attach significance to the risk, or the doctor is or should reasonably be aware that the particular patient would be likely to attach significance to it.' (Lord Kerr)
• 'Neither the doctor nor the patient is the arbiter of objective reasonableness. The assessment of what risks and benefits would be reasonable to disclose, and how they should be presented and assessed, in any given case is a matter for expert judgment. In making that assessment, the doctor must take into account the characteristics of the patient, including her age, her sex, her state of health, and all other relevant aspects of her medical condition. He must also take into account any other medication which she is currently taking.' (Lord Kerr)

cases.name: R (on the application of Evans) and another (Respondents) v Attorney General (Appellant) [2015] UKSC 21
cases.summary:
Facts
• The case of R (on the application of Evans) and another (Respondents) v Attorney General (Appellant) [2015] UKSC 21 concerns the disclosure of the “black spider memos” written by Prince Charles to government officials.
• The memos contained the Prince’s views on a range of topics, including architecture, the environment, and healthcare.

Issues
• The main issue in the case was whether the Attorney General acted lawfully in refusing to disclose the memos in response to a Freedom of Information Act request.
• The respondents argued that the memos were of public interest and should be disclosed, while the appellant argued that the memos were part of the Prince’s private correspondence and therefore exempt from disclosure.

Decision
• The Supreme Court held that the Attorney General’s decision to refuse disclosure was unlawful.
• The Court found that the memos were “advocacy correspondence” rather than purely private correspondence, and therefore subject to disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act.
• The Court rejected the appellant’s argument that disclosure of the memos would harm the Prince’s ability to perform his duties as heir to the throne, stating that the public has a legitimate interest in knowing the views expressed by the Prince on matters of public policy.

Key passage(s)
• '...advocacy correspondence is not the same as ordinary correspondence. It is written by the Prince of Wales in order to advance the work of charities, to promote views and to seek feedback. In general, it is sent to government ministers and officials, and it is marked ‘not for publication’. It is not part of the normal system of communication between a private individual and public authorities. Rather, it is a means by which the Prince of Wales can express his views and seek to influence the government on matters about which he feels strongly, either through his own experiences or as a result of the concerns expressed to him by others' (Lord Mance).
• 'However, the public interest will not usually justify the disclosure of purely personal or confidential information or opinions, or exchanges intended to be confidential. Nor will it usually justify the disclosure of information or opinions relating to internal discussions and consultations within government, or between government departments and other public bodies' (Lord Neuberger).

cases.name: R (on the application of Moseley) (in substitution of Stirling (Deceased)) (AP) (Appellant) v London Borough of Haringey (Respondent) [2014] UKSC 56
cases.summary:
Facts
• The London Borough of Haringey ('the Council') introduced a council tax reduction scheme following a decrease in central government funding for the tax.
• The Council sought public opinions before implementing the scheme.
• Moseley, a citizen of Haringey, sought judicial review of the process on the grounds that the consultation process was unfair in accordance with R (Morgan) v Richmond-upon-Thames LBC [2011] EWCA Civ 904 ('Morgan').

Issues
• Moseley argued that the consultation process was inadequate and the Council failed to present other possible alternatives, which breached public fairness requirements.
• The Council contended that they abided by the standards established in Morgan, and they had sufficiently informed consultees of the proposed changes.

Decision
• The UK Supreme Court allowed Moseley's appeal.
• The court found that the Council had breached public fairness requirements as they failed to provide enough information in the consultation process and failed to consider alternatives.
• The court established new principles on consultation standards to ensure a fair process for public decision-making.

Key passage(s)
• 'The demands of fairness are likely to be somewhat higher when consultation of individuals is required by statute than when it is embarked on as a matter of discretion.' (Lord Reed)
• 'The purpose of consultation is not to enable informed criticism of a decision which has already been taken, but to enable consultation responses to be

when the decision is ultimately taken.' (Lord Wilson)
• 'Fairness requires that, if the council chooses to consult, it must consult properly. Its consultation must be a genuine opportunity for the consultees to express their views on the proposal and for the authority to take those views into account when finalising its proposals.' (Lord Hodge)

cases.name: R (on the application of Nicklinson and another) (AP) (Appellants) v Ministry of Justice (Respondent) [2014] UKSC 38
cases.summary:
Facts
• Tony Nicklinson suffered a stroke that left him with locked-in syndrome, a condition that left him unable to move or communicate.
• He wanted to end his life but was unable to do so without assistance due to the Suicide Act 1961.
• Nicklinson and another individual, Paul Lamb, brought a case before the court seeking a declaration that the Suicide Act 1961 was incompatible with their right to a private life under Article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the Suicide Act 1961 was incompatible with the appellants' right to a private life under Article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights.
• The appellants argued that the law violated their right to autonomy and self-determination.
• The respondent, the Ministry of Justice, argued that it was not for the courts to change the law on assisted suicide.

Decision
• The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the appeal.
• The court held that it was not for the courts to change the law on assisted suicide, as it was a matter for Parliament to decide.
• The court noted that Parliament had considered the issue of assisted suicide on several occasions but had chosen not to change the law.
• The court also noted that the European Court of Human Rights had not found that the right to a private life under Article 8 included a right to assisted suicide.

Key passage(s)
• 'The question for the court is whether the blanket ban on assisted suicide imposed by section 2(1) of the Suicide Act 1961 is a proportionate means of achieving the legitimate aim of the protection of the weak and vulnerable in society.' (Lord Neuberger)
• 'The question of whether the law should permit assisted suicide is a matter for Parliament to decide, not the courts.' (Lord Neuberger)

cases.name: R (on the application of HS2 Action Alliance Limited) (Appellant) v The Secretary of State for Transport and another (Respondents) [2014] UKSC 3
cases.summary:
Facts:
• The Secretary of State for Transport issued the HS2 high-speed rail project's command paper and environmental statement.
• HS2 Action Alliance Limited, a group of local authorities and residents, challenged the legality of the decisions based on: 1) the Strategic Environmental Assessment (SEA) Directive and 2) the Aarhus Convention.
• The High Court rejected the claim, and the Court of Appeal upheld the decision.

Issues:
• The appellant argued that the command paper should have been subjected to an SEA before adoption.
• The respondent countered that an SEA was not required because the command paper was not a 'plan or programme within the meaning of the SEA Directive.
• Lastly, the appellant claimed a breach of the Aarhus Convention due to insufficient public participation.

Decision:
• The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the appeal.
• The Court ruled that the command paper was not a 'plan or programme' subject to an SEA, in line withSave Historic Newmarket Ltd v Forest Heath District Council [2011] EWHC 606 (Admin)
• Additionally, the Court found no breach of the Aarhus Convention relating to public participation.

Key passage(s):
• 'It is to be treated as established by [Save Historic Newmarket], that a national policy statement, whether designated or not, is not a plan or programme setting the framework for future development consent within the meaning of article 3(2)(a) of the SEA Directive.' - Lord Carnwath
• 'The defendant's decision to introduce a Hybrid Bill incorporating safeguarding directions of the kind described in his Command Paper was not in any event a decision within article 7 (as the claimants contend) but a decision within article 8.' - Lord Carnwath
• 'The court should be slow to intervene in the process of Parliamentary scrutiny of the legislative proposals: that is the constitutional role of Parliament.' - Lord Reed

cases.name: R (on the application of Chester) (Appellant) v Secretary of State for Justice (Respondent) [2013] UKSC 63
cases.summary:
Facts
• The appellant, Chester, was a convicted sex offender who had completed his custodial sentence but was subject to a lifelong notification requirement under the Sexual Offences Act 2003.
• Chester argued that the notification requirement violated his human rights, specifically his right to respect for private and family life under Article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR).

Issues
• The main issue was whether the notification requirement under the Sexual Offences Act 2003 was compatible with Article 8 of the ECHR.
• Chester argued that it was not, while the Secretary of State for Justice argued that it was necessary for the protection of the public.

Decision
• The Supreme Court held that the notification requirement under the Sexual Offences Act 2003 was incompatible with Article 8 of the ECHR.
• The Court found that the notification requirement was disproportionate and unjustified, and that it imposed a blanket requirement without regard to individual circumstances.
• The Court also noted that there was no evidence to support the effectiveness of the notification requirement in reducing reoffending.

Key passage(s)
• 'The notification requirements have a very significant impact on the article 8 rights of those affected by them. They are open-ended, potentially lasting for life, and there is a significant stigma attached to them, in terms of the adverse effect on the offender's relationship with his family and in society generally. Moreover, they are imposed on offenders who have served the sentences imposed on them by the courts and who, in many cases, have been assessed as posing no significant risk of reoffending' (para. 50, Lord Reed).
• 'The imposition of the notification requirements on the appellant, in the absence of any consideration of his individual circumstances, was disproportionate and unjustified. It follows that the requirements were incompatible with his article 8 rights' (para. 97, Lord Reed).

cases.name: Walumba Lumba (Congo) 1 and 2 (Appellants) v Secretary of State for the Home Department (Respondent) [2011] UKSC 12
cases.summary:
Facts
• Walumba Lumba, a national of the Democratic Republic of Congo, and Kadian Mighty, a Jamaican national, were detained pending deportation.
• Both appellants had criminal convictions and were detained under Immigration Act 1971, Schedule 3, paragraph 2(2) after the Secretary of State for the Home Department (SSHD) decided to deport them.
• However, the deportation orders could not be enforced immediately, and the appellants remained in detention.
• They challenged their detention, arguing it was unlawful under common law and Article 5 of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR).

Issues
• The appellants argued their detention was unlawful because the SSHD failed to follow her own published policy on detention and had a secret, more restrictive policy.
• The SSHD contended she had the power to detain pending deportation under the Immigration Act 1971 and did not need to follow the published policy.

Decision
• The UK Supreme Court held the detention of Lumba and Mighty was unlawful.
• The Court found that the SSHD's failure to follow her published policy amounted to a breach of the appellants' common law right to be treated fairly.
• Furthermore, the Court found that the appellant's detention was unlawful under Article 5 of the ECHR because it was arbitrary and therefore not

Key passage(s)
• 'Where a published policy sets out how an individual's rights will be safeguarded, there is a legitimate expectation that the policy will be applied to that individual’s case.' (Lord Dyson)
• 'The failure to follow the published policy in the present case is a potent example of how unlawful conduct can infect executive decision-making with unfairness.' (Lord Dyson)
• 'In the circumstances of the present cases, the refusal of the Secretary of State to apply her published policy is, in my opinion, indeed an abuse of power. It is therefore a ground for quashing the decision to detain the appellants.' (Lord Rodger)

cases.name: AXA General Insurance Ltd v HM Advocate and others (Scotland) [2011] UKSC 46
cases.summary:
Facts
• A group of claimants brought actions against AXA General Insurance Ltd and other insurers in the Scottish courts, alleging that the insurers were liable for personal injury caused by asbestos.
• In response, the insurance companies sought to rely on legislation passed by the Scottish Parliament which limited their liability by providing an exemption from liability for certain insurers (The Damages (Asbestos-related Conditions) (Scotland) Act 2009).
• The insurers argued that this legislation was rendered invalid by the Scotland Act 1998, as it engaged with the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) and the rights conferred under the EU law.

Issues
• The insurers argued that the Scottish legislation was incompatible with their rights under Article 1 of Protocol 1 to the ECHR (providing for the right to peaceful enjoyment of possessions).
• The claimants countered that the legislation was a proportionate means of achieving the legitimate aim of securing compensation for incurred personal injury.
• Both parties agreed that the compatibility of the legislation with EU law was not in question.

Decision
• The UK Supreme Court rejected the insurers' arguments and upheld the validity of the Scottish legislation.
• The Court held that the legislation pursued a legitimate aim - specifically, the protection of the rights of those suffering from asbestos-related diseases.
• The Court also found that the measures in the legislation were proportionate to that aim, falling within the margin of appreciation afforded to the Scottish Parliament in balancing competing interests.

Key passage(s)
• 'We do not consider that the 2009 Act has any effect on property rights that entitles the appellants to rely on A1P1.' (Lord Hope)
• 'The Scottish Parliament must have broad discretion when striking a balance between the competing public and private interests at stake, and it appears to us that it acted well within that discretion in passing the 2009 Act.' (Lord Hope)

cases.name: Radmacher (formerly Granatino) v Granatino [2010] UKSC 42
cases.summary:
Facts
• Katrin Radmacher (Radmacher), a German national, and Nicolas Granatino (Granatino), a French national, met in London in 1997.
• Radmacher was a wealthy heiress, while Granatino was a banker.
• They married in 1998 and had two children.
• Prior to their wedding, Radmacher asked Granatino to sign a prenuptial agreement (PNA) to protect her assets in the event of a divorce.
• Granatino signed the agreement without seeking legal advice.
• In 2006, the couple separated and divorced.
• Granatino contested the validity of the PNA, arguing that it was unfair and that he had signed it under duress.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the PNA should be enforced, given that Granatino had signed it without seeking legal advice and claimed that he had done so under duress.
• The Court of Appeal had held that the PNA was unenforceable, while Radmacher had appealed to the Supreme Court.

Decision
• The Supreme Court allowed Radmacher's appeal and held that the PNA was enforceable.
• The court noted that PNAs were not contrary to public policy and that the parties should be held to their agreements unless there were good reasons not to do so.
• The court held that the existence of the PNA did not indicate that the parties did not intend to be bound by it, and that Granatino had failed to establish that he had signed it under duress.
• The court also held that the fact that Granatino had not sought legal advice was not sufficient to render the agreement unenforceable.

Key passage(s)
• 'The court should give effect to a nuptial agreement that is freely entered into by each party with a full appreciation of its implications unless in the circumstances prevailing it would not be fair to hold the parties to their agreement' (Lord Phillips)
• 'In the present case, in my view, it is impossible to say that it was unfair to hold the husband to the agreement that he freely made and that was clearly understood by both parties to regulate their financial affairs in the event of divorce' (Lord Collins)

cases.name: R (on the application of Cart) v The Upper Tribunal [2011] UKSC 28
cases.summary:
Facts
• In this 2011 Supreme Court case, the claimant, Ms. Cart, sought judicial review of a decision made by the Upper Tribunal.
• The Upper Tribunal had dismissed her appeal against a decision of the Asylum and Immigration Tribunal regarding her entitlement to benefits.
• Ms. Cart argued that the Upper Tribunal's decision should be open to judicial review, as there was an error of law in the way the Upper Tribunal had reached its decision.

Issues
• The central issue in this case was whether decisions of the Upper Tribunal could be subject to judicial review.
• Ms. Cart argued that the decisions of the Upper Tribunal should be reviewable if they involved an error of law.
• The Upper Tribunal argued that its decisions should not be open to judicial review because it was a statutory appellate body, and its decisions were supposed to be final.
• Prior to this case, there had been conflicting interpretations in lower courts on what circumstances would allow for decisions of the Upper Tribunal to be subject to judicial review.

Decision
• The court ruled that decisions of the Upper Tribunal can be judicially reviewed, but only in limited circumstances.
• The court held that a decision of the Upper Tribunal would only be reviewable if it involved an error of law that was 'of truly exceptional public importance'.
• The court also clarified that the test for what constitutes 'truly exceptional public importance' would be similar to the test for the grant of leave to appeal from the Court of Appeal to the Supreme Court.

Key passage(s)
• 'It is for the courts to determine the extent of their supervisory jurisdiction over the Upper Tribunals. And it is for the courts to preserve, both in the law they declare and interpret, and in the extent of the relief they are prepared to grant, that balance between the rights of the individual and the demands of the efficient administration of justice which is the cornerstone of our public law.' (Lord Dyson)
• 'The more objectionable it would be, as a matter of constitutional principle, to exclude the supervisory jurisdiction of the High Court altogether, the more ready the court may be to recognise that an error of law is of such a kind as to justify the grant of permission.' (Lord Phillips)

cases.name: R (on the application of E) (Respondent) v JFS Governing Body (Appellant) [2009] UKSC 15
cases.summary:
Facts
• The JFS Governing Body (JFS) is an Orthodox Jewish school in London that gives priority to children who are Jewish according to the Orthodox definition.
• E applied for admission to JFS but was rejected as her mother's mother was not Jewish according to the Orthodox definition.
• E challenged the decision, arguing that it was discriminatory.

Issues
• The main issue in this case was whether JFS's admissions policy, which gave priority to children who are Jewish according to the Orthodox definition, was discriminatory under the Race Relations Act 1976 (RRA) and the Equality Act 2006 (EA).
• E argued that the policy was discriminatory, while JFS argued that it was a legitimate way of maintaining a Jewish ethos.

Decision
• The Supreme Court held that JFS's admissions policy was discriminatory under the RRA and the EA.
• The Court found that the policy was not a proportionate means of achieving a legitimate aim, as it discriminated against children who were Jewish but did not meet the Orthodox definition.
• The Court also found that the policy was not necessary to maintain a Jewish ethos, as there were other ways of doing so that did not involve discrimination.

Key passage(s)
• Lord Phillips 'Direct discrimination on grounds of race or ethnic or national origins is unlawful. It is unlawful regardless of whether it is conscious or unconscious, intentional or unintentional. The fact that the criterion applied by JFS may have a religious connotation does not mean that it is not discriminatory' [para. 21].
• Lady Hale 'If a school such as JFS admits any pupils who are not Jewish according to the Orthodox definition, then the argument that it is necessary to admit only those who are in order to maintain a Jewish ethos is weakened. It is not the religion of the pupil which matters, but the religion of the school' [para. 88].

cases.name: R (on the application of Purdy) v Director of Public Prosecutions [2009] UKHL 45
cases.summary:
Facts
• Debbie Purdy suffered from multiple sclerosis and wished to end her life at a time of her choosing.
• She sought clarification from the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) on whether her husband would be prosecuted for assisting her suicide if she travelled to Switzerland to end her life.
• The DPP refused to provide clarification, stating that each case would be decided on its own facts.
• Purdy brought a case seeking clarification on the law of assisted suicide.

Issues
• The issue in this case was whether the DPP's refusal to provide clarification on the law of assisted suicide was a breach of Purdy's right to respect for private life under Article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR).
• Purdy argued that the lack of clarity on the law made it impossible for her to make an informed decision about whether to end her life.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the DPP's refusal to provide clarification on the law of assisted suicide was a breach of Purdy's Article 8 rights.
• The court held that the DPP had a duty to clarify the law to enable individuals to make an informed decision about whether to end their life.
• The court outlined a set of factors that the DPP should consider when deciding whether to prosecute someone for assisting suicide, including the motivation of the person assisting, the final acts of the deceased, and the overall circumstances of the case.

Key passage(s)
• 'Article 8 of the ECHR is engaged because the DPP's policy has an impact on the manner in which the applicant can exercise her right to autonomy and self-determination when deciding whether to end her life.' - Lord Hope (para. 9)
• 'The DPP must provide an indication of the factors that he would take into account in deciding whether or not to consent to a prosecution in cases of assisted suicide.' - Lord Hope (para. 40)

cases.name: R (on the application of Gentle) v Prime Minister [2008] UKHL 20
cases.summary:
Facts
• In this case, the appellants were relatives of UK service personnel killed whilst on duty during the conflict in Iraq in 2003.
• They sought a ruling that the UK government was under a procedural obligation, derived from Article 2 (right to life) of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR), to establish an independent and public inquiry into the lawfulness of the government’s decision to use military force against Iraq.

Issues
• The appellants argued that the disclosure obligations required by Article 2 under R (Middleton) v West Somerset Coroner [2004] UKHL 10, [2004] 2 AC 182 were not satisfied, as the investigations into the servicemen’s deaths did not address the underlying legality of the use of force.
• The government argued that Article 2 did not impose a duty to conduct an inquiry in these circumstances.

Decision
• The House of Lords rejected the appellants’ argument and found in favor of the government.
• Both the majority and the minority considered that the procedural obligation to investigate death under Article 2 was limited to cases where the victims had died “within the jurisdiction” of the UK, which extended only to cases where the victims were within the physical control of the UK authorities.
• The majority also pointed out that there was no substantive violation of Article 2 itself, which weakened the argument for the procedural obligation to investigate.
• The minority disagreed on this point, noting that the procedural obligations did not depend on a violation of the substantive right.

Key passage(s)
• 'The scope of the duty to investigate must depend on the relationship between the substantive right and the procedural obligation it is designed to promote.' (Baroness Hale)
• 'To the extent that Middleton, while not establishing any free-standing right of access to a court, demonstrates an incremental expansion of the procedural obligations under Article 2, that development is confined to situations with a proper UK jurisdictional nexus.' (Lord Brown)
• 'There is no reason to suppose that the procedural obligation extends beyond those cases where the substantive obligation extends.' (Lord Scott)

cases.name: Stack v Dowden [2007] UKHL 17
cases.summary:
Facts
• Stack v Dowden [2007] UKHL 17 concerns the division of the proceeds from the sale of a property between two cohabitants, Ms Dowden and Mr Stack.
• They had lived together for 18 years, had three children together, and had purchased the property in joint names.

Issues
• The main issue was the nature and extent of the parties' beneficial interests in the property.
• Ms Dowden argued that their interests were equal, as they had purchased the property in joint names and had contributed equally to the purchase price and mortgage payments.
• Mr Stack argued that he was entitled to a greater share of the proceeds, as he had made larger contributions to the property's purchase and maintenance.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that there was no presumption of joint beneficial ownership of the property, and that the extent of each party's interest would depend on their common intention at the time of purchase.
• In this case, the parties had intended to own the property jointly and equally, and therefore their beneficial interests were equal.
• However, the court recognized that the parties had conducted their financial affairs separately, and that this might indicate a contrary intention.
• Therefore, the court considered the parties' whole course of conduct, including their financial arrangements and contributions, to determine their common intention.

Key passage(s)
• 'It is not possible to lay down any hard and fast rule as to the identification of the relevant common intention. Everything depends on the context in which the question arises.' (Lord Walker)
• 'In most cases where there is evidence of joint legal ownership, it will readily be inferred, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, that the parties intended to beneficially own the property in equal shares.' (Baroness Hale)

cases.name: R (on the application of Jackson) v Attorney General [2005] UKHL 56
cases.summary:
Facts
• The Hunting Act 2004 (the Act) banned hunting wild mammals with dogs.
• Mr Jackson challenged the Act, arguing that it was incompatible with the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) and that it was enacted using an improper parliamentary procedure.
• The case was heard by the House of Lords, which is now known as the Supreme Court.

Issues
• The main issues in the case were whether the Act was incompatible with the ECHR, particularly Article 1 of the First Protocol (A1P1), which protects the right to peaceful enjoyment of possessions, and whether the Act was enacted using an improper parliamentary procedure.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the Act was not incompatible with A1P1 as it did not interfere with any existing property rights.
• The court also held that the Act was enacted using a proper parliamentary procedure and that the Parliament Act 1949 (which allows the House of Commons to override the House of Lords in certain circumstances) was not unconstitutional.

Key passage(s)
• Lord Hope, in his judgment, stated 'The question whether the Hunting Act 2004 is compatible with the Convention is one of substance, not procedure. The court is concerned with whether the effect of the legislation is to interfere with the rights protected by the Convention, not with whether the appropriate procedures have been followed in Parliament' [para. 49].
• Lord Bingham, in his judgment, stated 'The Hunting Act 2004 was passed in the way that Parliament prescribed for it. It has not been suggested that any provision of the Act was beyond the legislative competence of Parliament. The Act is not incompatible with the Convention. It must be accepted as law' [para. 1].

cases.name: Campbell v Mirror Group Newspapers Ltd [2004] UKHL 22
cases.summary:
Facts
• Naomi Campbell, a well-known model, attended Narcotics Anonymous meetings and it was reported in the Mirror newspaper that she was attending these meetings.
• Campbell sued the Mirror Group Newspapers Ltd for breach of confidence and claimed that her privacy had been violated.
• The Mirror Group Newspapers argued that Naomi Campbell had sought publicity of her attendance at the meetings in order to gain positive publicity for her image.

Issues
• The main issue in this case was whether Naomi Campbell's privacy had been violated when the Mirror Group Newspapers reported on her attendance at Narcotics Anonymous meetings.
• Additionally, the case raised questions about the balance between freedom of expression and the right to privacy.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that Naomi Campbell's privacy had been violated by the Mirror Group Newspapers.
• The court found that there was no public interest in publishing the information about Campbell's attendance at the meetings.
• The court also found that even if there was a public interest, it did not outweigh Campbell's right to privacy.

Key passage(s)
• 'Whether something is private must depend on all the circumstances. Although the circumstances in which the information comes into the public domain may be relevant, they are not determinative. For example, in some cases, the fact that information is already known to a section of the public may make it more likely that its further dissemination will not give rise to a reasonable expectation of privacy. But the fact that information is in the public domain does not necessarily mean that there is no reasonable expectation of privacy in relation to further dissemination of that information.' (Lord Nicholls)
• 'The touchstone of private life is not whether a person is in a public place or a private place but whether in all the circumstances the person has a reasonable expectation of privacy.' (Lord Hope)
• 'It is not necessary to show that the disclosure was motivated by a desire to injure the claimant or for any other improper purpose. It is sufficient if the disclosure is offensive to a reasonable person of ordinary sensibilities.' (Lord Nicholls)

cases.name: R (on the application of Limbuela) v Secretary of State for the Home Department [2005] UKHL 66
cases.summary:
Facts
• Three asylum seekers were denied support under section 55 of the Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act 2002 (s.55) because they failed to make their claims 'as soon as reasonably practicable'.
• They were destitute, without access to food, clothing or shelter, and at risk of inhuman or degrading treatment.
• The claimants argued that the denial of support under s.55 violated their rights under Article 3 of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR), which prohibits inhuman or degrading treatment.

Issues
• The Secretary of State argued that s.55 did not engage Article 3 and that even if it did, support could be provided under section 95 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (s.95) to avoid a violation.
• The claimants argued that denial of support under s.55 amounted to inhuman or degrading treatment in violation of Article 3 ECHR.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the denial of support under s.55 was capable of being inhuman or degrading treatment in violation of Article 3 ECHR.
• They found that the operation of s.55 in these circumstances did amount to inhuman or degrading treatment.
• The Lords held that s.95 support could be provided to avoid a violation of Article 3.

Key passage(s)
• 'The threshold may be crossed when a late applicant for asylum, who is genuinely hungry, cold and at risk of deteriorating mental and physical health, is denied even the most basic support' - (Lord Bingham).
• 'Section 55 does not apply to a claimant who is already being supported under s.95, but the Secretary of State may not deny support under s.55 in circumstances where it is required by the claimant's rights under Article 3' - (Lord Brown).

cases.name: A v Secretary of State for the Home Department [2004] UKHL 56
cases.summary:
Facts
• The 'A' in the case name refers to nine appellants who were all foreign nationals accused of terrorist acts in their home countries. The United Kingdom was not able to deport them due to the risk of them facing torture or inhumane treatment in their home countries. In response Parliament enacted the Anti-terrorism, Crime and Security Act 2001 (ATCSA).
• Under Part 4 of the ATCSA, the Secretary of State for the Home Department issued certificates naming the appellants as suspected international terrorists, leading to their detention without trial.
• The appellants appealed their detention under the ATCSA.

Issues
• The appellants claimed their detention was incompatible with their rights under the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR), particularly Article 5 (the right to liberty and security) and Article 14 (prohibition of discrimination).
• The Secretary of State argued that the legislation was a justified and proportionate response to the public emergency threatening the life of UK citizens.

Decision
• The UK House of Lords held that the detention of the appellants without trial under Part 4 of the ATCSA was incompatible with their human rights under the ECHR.
• It found that the legislation was discriminatory because it only applied to foreign nationals and not to British citizens suspected of terrorist acts, contrary to Article 14.
• The Court also concluded that the detention powers were disproportionate and failed the test for legitimate derogations under Article 15 of the ECHR.

Key passage(s)
• 'The real threat to the life of the nation ... comes not from terrorism but from laws such as these.' (Lord Hoffmann)
• 'Even in situations when all values cherished by free societies are threatened, it is essential to uphold human rights to ensure that the foundations of these societies are not undermined.' (Lord Bingham)

cases.name: R (on the application of H) v Mental Health Review Tribunal for the North and East London Region and the Secretary of State for Health [2005] UKHL 60
cases.summary:
Facts
• H was a patient detained under Section 3 of the Mental Health Act 1983 (MHA 1983) and sought her discharge from detention.
• The Mental Health Review Tribunal (MHRT) had not decided to discharge her.
• On judicial review, H challenged: (1) a decision of the MHRT, which refused to discharge her from detention, and (2) a decision by the Secretary of State for Health which upheld the tribunal's decision.

Issues
• H argued that the MHRT and the Secretary of State for Health contravened Article 5(4) of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) by not providing a speedy review of the lawfulness of her detention.
• The respondents argued that there was no breach of Article 5(4) ECHR and that domestic law and procedure was compatible with the Article 5(4) right to a speedy review.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the domestic law and procedure were compatible with Article 5(4) ECHR, ruling in favor of the respondents.
• Their Lordships dismissed H's appeal, stating that the process leading up to the MHRT's decision and the Secretary of State's executive review had been both thorough and expeditious.
• The House of Lords made clear that in order to comply with Article 5(4), speediness needs to be assessed in light of the thoroughness of the review process and the particular circumstances of each case.

Key passage(s)
• 'For the time being, the relation between the state's duty to provide institutions and facilities to discharge their duty to use reasonable dispatch in determining the lawfulness of detention under Article 5(4) and the rights of the patient admitted under s. 3 must be held to be sufficiently indicated by the requirement of procedural expeditiousness which I have endeavored to articulate above.' - Lord Hope (para 47)
• 'What is required by Art 5(4) is that the procedure before the tribunal should be conducted with all due expedition which the patient's circumstances allow.' - Lord Rodgers (para 128)

cases.name: Regina v Bartle and the Commissioner of Police for the Metropolis and Others, Ex Parte Pinochet [1999] UKHL 1
cases.summary:
Facts
• Augusto Pinochet, the former president of Chile, was arrested in London in 1998 on a Spanish warrant seeking his extradition to Spain to face charges of torture and conspiracy to torture during his regime.
• Pinochet claimed immunity as a former head of state.
• The case went to the House of Lords, which had to decide whether Pinochet was entitled to immunity from prosecution under international law.

Issues
• The main issue in this case was whether Pinochet was entitled to immunity from prosecution under international law.
• Pinochet argued that he was entitled to immunity as a former head of state.
• The other issue was whether the crimes Pinochet was accused of were extraditable offenses.

Decision
• The House of Lords ruled that Pinochet was not entitled to immunity from prosecution as a former head of state.
• The Lords held that the nature of the crimes Pinochet was accused of, namely torture and conspiracy to torture, were not covered by the doctrine of state immunity.
• Therefore, Pinochet could be extradited to Spain to face trial.
• However, the Lords also ruled that Pinochet was entitled to immunity in relation to acts committed in the exercise of his functions as a head of state.

Key passage(s)
• Lord Browne-Wilkinson 'Crimes such as torture, hostage-taking and genocide are crimes under international law, whether committed by rulers or private individuals. The principle of international law which excludes state immunity from jurisdiction in respect of such crimes thus reflects the fundamental moral principle that no state, no ruler, no official and no individual has licence to commit such crimes' (para. 13).
• Lord Millett 'Crimes against humanity are crimes against all mankind. No sovereign or head of state can claim immunity from the jurisdiction of the courts of another state where he is accused of committing such crimes' (para. 98).

cases.name: Fairchild v Glenhaven Funeral Services Ltd and others [2002] UKHL 22
cases.summary:
Facts
• Fairchild worked as an apprentice for various firms, including Glenhaven Funeral Services Ltd.
• During his employment, he was exposed to asbestos, which ultimately led to his contracting mesothelioma, a cancer of the lining of the lungs.
• The exposure to asbestos occurred during different periods of employment, and it was impossible to determine which exposure caused the illness.
• Fairchild brought a claim against all the firms he had worked for, alleging that each of them had contributed to his illness.

Issues
• The main issue was whether Fairchild could succeed in his claim against his employers despite the inability to prove which employer's exposure caused his illness.
• The employers argued that they should not be held liable for Fairchild's mesothelioma because it was impossible to establish which of them had caused the harm.
• Fairchild, on the other hand, argued that because he had contracted the illness due to the employers' negligence, each employer should be held liable for his injuries.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that in mesothelioma cases, where a claimant had been exposed to asbestos by more than one employer, and it was impossible to prove which exposure had caused the illness, each employer should be held liable for the full extent of the damage caused.
• This decision departed from the traditional 'but for' causation test, which requires a claimant to prove that the defendant's actions were the cause of the harm suffered.
• The court held that the burden of proof should be reversed in such cases, and the employers should bear the burden of proving that they did not cause the harm.

Key passage(s)
• 'The defendants' submission is that the chain of causation is broken because the mesothelioma could have been caused by exposure not attributable to any of them. I reject that submission. The mesothelioma was caused by a combination of factors, including the exposure to asbestos dust of each employer. Each exposure contributed to the mesothelioma and so to the damage suffered by the Claimant.' (Lord Bingham)
• 'In my view, the law should recognize that there are exceptional cases in which the 'but for' test of causation may properly be relaxed. The present case, in which the Claimant has worked for a number of different employers, each of whom has materially increased the risk of his developing mesothelioma, is one such case.' (Lord Hoffmann)

cases.name: R (on the application of Anderson) v Secretary of State for the Home Department [2002] UKHL 46
cases.summary:
Facts
• The applicant, Anthony Anderson, was convicted of murder in 1988 and sentenced to life imprisonment.
• Under UK law at the time, the minimum term to be served (tariff) was determined by the Secretary of State for the Home Department (SSHD) based on recommendations from the judiciary.
• Anderson's tariff was established at 15 years, and at the end of this period, he applied for a review of his continued detention by the Lord Chief Justice.
• The Lord Chief Justice recommended reducing his tariff to 10 years, but the SSHD disagreed and maintained it at 15 years.
• Anderson sought judicial review of the SSHD's decision.

Issues
• Anderson argued that the SSHD's decision-making process violated his right to a fair trial under Article 6(1) of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) due to its lack of independence and impartiality.
• The SSHD argued that Article 6(1) did not apply as the decision was not a determination of a criminal charge, but rather a part of the sentence execution process.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the SSHD's role in determining tariffs did in fact violate Anderson's right to a fair trial under Article 6(1) of the ECHR.
• The House of Lords followed the European Court of Human Rights' decisions in T v United Kingdom and V v United Kingdom, which stated that tariff decisions did come under the ambit of Article 6(1).
• They noted that the involvement of a political figure (SSHD) in making decisions on tariffs was inconsistent with the ECHR's requirements for impartiality and independence.
• The decision in Anderson led to the abolition of the SSHD's role in determining tariffs and the establishment of the independent Sentencing Guidelines Council.

Key passage(s)
• 'There is an obvious and fundamental difference between the role of the judge in sentencing, and that of the Secretary of State in setting the tariff.' (Lord Bingham)
• 'Where Convention rights are in issue, the courts must…only depart from the principles laid down by the Court [of Human Rights] if they are plainly wrong or inconsistent with some fundamental substantive or procedural aspect of our law.' (Lord Steyn)
• 'The fixing of the tariff is an integral part of the sentencing process. The Secretary of State is not a judicial body…he is not impartial…and his decision…are[sic] not appealable as of right.' (Lord Woolf)

cases.name: R v Secretary of State for the Home Department, ex parte Simms [2000] UKHL 5
R v Secretary of State for the Home Department, ex parte Daly [2001] UKHL 26
cases.summary:
Facts
• The applicants, two prisoners, were convicted of separate murders and given life sentences.
• They sought to challenge the fairness of their trials through interviews with investigative journalists.
• The Home Secretary imposed restrictions under the Prison Rules, preventing prisoners from having oral or written communication with journalists unless the communication was in the public interest.
• The prisoners sought judicial review of these restrictions, arguing they violated their rights to freedom of expression under the European Convention on Human Rights.

Issues
• The applicants argued that the restrictions violated their rights to freedom of expression under the European Convention on Human Rights.
• The Home Secretary argued that the restrictions were necessary to maintain discipline and deter crime.

Decision
• The House of Lords allowed the prisoners' appeals and held that the restrictions were disproportionate and violated their rights to freedom of expression under the European Convention on Human Rights.
• The court applied the common law principle of legality: Parliament must expressly restrict fundamental rights, and courts should interpret statutes to preserve these rights where possible.
• The court found that the restrictions were not strictly necessary and had not been shown to be the least restrictive means of achieving their intended objectives.

Key passage(s)
• 'In the absence of express language or necessary implication to the contrary, the courts therefore presume that even the most general words were intended to be subject to the basic rights of the individual.' (Lord Hoffmann)
• 'Fundamental rights cannot be overridden by general or ambiguous words.' (Lord Steyn)

cases.name: McFarlane v Tayside Health Board (Scotland) [2000] 2 AC 59 (HL)
cases.summary:
Facts
• In McFarlane v Tayside Health Board, Mr. and Mrs. McFarlane, a married couple, sought damages for the cost of raising their child who was conceived as a result of a negligently performed vasectomy.
• Mr. McFarlane underwent a vasectomy in September 1990, and the Health Board failed to provide adequate advice on contraception after the operation.
• Upon being told that the operation was successful and no further contraception was required, the couple conceived a child later in the pregnancy.

Issues
• The main issue before the House of Lords was whether the parents could recover, as damages, the cost of raising the child from the Health Board who negligently performed the vasectomy.
• The claimants argued that the Health Board was responsible for the costs, as it was a direct consequence of their negligence.
• The Health Board contended that the damages should not be awarded on the grounds that the birth of a healthy child is not a loss which can be compensated.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the parents could not recover the costs of raising the child. Although the Health Board had breached their duty of care, they were not liable to pay the expenses associated with raising the child, as the birth of a healthy child is not a loss capable of being remedied.
• They considered the case of Doyle v Olby Ironmongers Ltd [1969] 2 QB 158 and held that it was distinguishable from the present case, as it allowed for compensation for the loss of capacity to have children rather than for the birth of a child.
• Furthermore, awarding damages for raising a child would be against the public interest as it could potentially deter life-enhancing health care treatment.

Key passage(s):
• Lord Steyn: 'The general answer to the question whether a person may sue for damages for the costs of bringing up a child is that the law regards the birth of a normal, healthy child as a blessing and not as constituting a recognizable source of loss.'

Donoghue v Stevenson [1932] AC 562
cases.summary:
Facts
• In 1928, Mrs. Donoghue (plaintiff) went to a café with a friend who bought her a ginger beer in an opaque bottle.
• After drinking some of the beer, she discovered a decomposing snail in the bottle, which made her ill.
• She sued Mr. Stevenson (defendant), the manufacturer, for damages.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the manufacturer of a product owed a duty of care to the ultimate consumer of the product.
• The plaintiff argued that the manufacturer was liable for the harm caused by the defective product, while the defendant argued that he had no duty to the plaintiff as she had not purchased the product from him.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the manufacturer owed a duty of care to the ultimate consumer.
• Lord Atkin formulated the

which provides that a person owes a duty of care to his neighbour, meaning those who are so closely and directly affected by his act that he ought reasonably to have them in contemplation as being so affected when he is directing his mind to the acts or omissions which are called in question.
• Applying this test, Lord Atkin found that a manufacturer owes a duty of care to the consumer of his products.

Key passage(s)
• 'The rule that you are to love your neighbour becomes in law, you must not injure your neighbour; and the lawyer's question, Who is my neighbour? receives a restricted reply. You must take reasonable care to avoid acts or omissions which you can reasonably foresee would be likely to injure your neighbour. Who, then, in law, is my neighbour? The answer seems to be - persons who are so closely and directly affected by my act that I ought reasonably to have them in contemplation as being so affected when I am directing my mind to the acts or omissions which are called in question.' (Lord Atkin)
• 'Where a manufacturer knows that the ultimate consumer of his product will not have the opportunity of examining the product for defects, the manufacturer owes a duty to the ultimate consumer to take reasonable care to ensure that the product is free from defects that may cause injury.' (Lord Macmillan)

cases.name: Caparo Industries plc v Dickman [1990] 2 AC 605
Rylands v Fletcher [1868] UKHL 1
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Rylands v Fletcher [1868] UKHL 1, the defendant owned a mill and constructed a reservoir on his land, which was near to the plaintiff’s (Rylands’) mine.
• The reservoir was built by independent contractors who were employed by the defendant, but who were careless in their construction.
• As a result, when the reservoir was filled with water, it burst and flooded Rylands’ mine, causing significant damage.

Issues
• The issue in this case was whether the defendant was liable for the damage caused by the flood.
• Rylands argued that the defendant was liable under the principle of nuisance, while the defendant argued that he was not liable because the reservoir was a natural use of his land.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the defendant was liable for the damage caused by the flood.
• The court established a new principle of liability, known as the rule in Rylands v Fletcher, which states that a person who brings onto their land something that is likely to do damage if it escapes will be liable for any damage caused by that thing if it does escape.
• The court held that the reservoir was a non-natural use of the land, as it involved the accumulation of a large amount of water in an artificial manner, and that the defendant was therefore liable for the damage caused by the flood.

Key passage(s)
• '…the person who for his own purposes brings on his lands and collects and keeps there anything likely to do mischief if it escapes, must keep it in at his peril, and if he does not do so is prima facie answerable for all the damage which is the natural consequence of its escape.' (Baron Blackburn)
• 'The rule which I think is applicable to this case is, that the person who for his own purposes brings on his land and collects and keeps there anything likely to do mischief if it escapes, must keep it at his peril, and, if he does not do so, is prima facie answerable for all the damage which is the natural consequence of its escape.' (Baron Bramwell)

cases.name: McLoughlin v O'Brian [1983] 1 AC 410
Bolam v Friern Hospital Management Committee [1957] 1 WLR 582
cases.summary:
Facts
• The plaintiff underwent electroconvulsive therapy at the defendant's hospital for his mental illness.
• During the treatment, the plaintiff suffered a fracture to his hip.
• The plaintiff claimed that the hospital was negligent in failing to take the necessary precautions to prevent such an injury.

Issues
• The primary issue was whether the hospital was negligent in its duty of care towards the plaintiff.
• The plaintiff argued that the hospital failed to take the necessary precautions to prevent his injury, while the hospital argued that they had followed the accepted medical practice at the time.

Decision
• The court held that the hospital was not negligent in its duty of care towards the plaintiff.
• The court applied the Bolam test, which states that a doctor is not negligent if they act in accordance with a practice accepted as proper by a responsible body of medical men skilled in that particular art.
• The court found that the hospital had followed the accepted medical practice at the time, and therefore, was not negligent.

Key passage(s)
• 'The test is the standard of the ordinary skilled man exercising and professing to have that special skill. A man need not possess the highest expert skill; it is well established law that it is sufficient if he exercises the ordinary skill of an ordinary competent man exercising that particular art.' (McNair J)
• 'The true test for establishing negligence in diagnosis or treatment on the part of a doctor is whether he has been proved to be guilty of such failure as no doctor of ordinary skill would be guilty of if acting with ordinary care.' (Devlin J)

Hedley Byrne & Co Ltd v Heller & Partners Ltd [1964] AC 465
cases.summary:
Facts
• Hedley Byrne & Co Ltd (plaintiff) was a firm of advertising agents who relied on financial information provided by Heller & Partners Ltd (defendant), a bank.
• Hedley Byrne sought advice from Heller regarding the financial position of a client who subsequently went into liquidation.
• Heller provided the advice, but it turned out to be incorrect, and Hedley Byrne suffered losses.
• Hedley Byrne sued Heller for negligent misstatement.

Issues
• The key issue was whether a duty of care existed between Heller and Hedley Byrne.
• The defendant argued that it had not assumed responsibility for the accuracy of the information it provided and that there was no special relationship between the parties that gave rise to a duty of care.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that a duty of care was owed by Heller to Hedley Byrne.
• The court found that a special relationship existed between the parties, as Hedley Byrne had made it clear that it was relying on Heller’s advice and had provided information about the use to which the advice would be put.
• The court stated that a duty of care could arise even in the absence of a contractual relationship and that a negligent misstatement could be actionable if it was made in circumstances where the speaker knew or ought to have known that the statement would be relied on by the recipient.

Key passage(s)
• Lord Devlin stated 'If someone possessed of a special skill undertakes, quite irrespective of contract, to apply that skill for the assistance of another person who relies upon such skill, a duty of care will arise. The fact that the service is to be given by means of or by the instrumentality of words can make no difference.'
• Lord Reid stated 'It is the law of Scotland that a person who, in the course of his business, profession or employment, gives advice to another person who relies upon it may in certain circumstances be liable to that person if the advice is negligently given. I think that this is also the law of England, but it is not necessary to decide that in this case.'
• Relevance
• This case established the principle of negligent misstatement, which has since been applied in many other cases. It also clarified the circumstances in which a duty of care could arise in the absence of a contractual relationship.

Home Office v Dorset Yacht Co Ltd [1970] AC 1004
cases.summary:
Facts
• In Home Office v Dorset Yacht Co Ltd [1970] AC 1004, a group of young offenders who were being held in Borstal training (an open institution for offenders) were placed on a small island to complete some repair work under the supervision of prison officers.
• The officers negligently failed to supervise the young offenders, who then escaped from the island and ended up causing significant damage to the claimant's yachts moored in the harbor nearby.

Issues
• The main issue in this case was whether the Home Office could be held liable for the damages incurred by the claimant due to the negligent supervision of the young offenders.
• The Home Office argued that there was no duty of care owed by them to the claimant, as the harm caused was too remote from the negligent act of supervision.
• The claimant contended that the Home Office was liable as the damage was foreseeable and a direct result of their negligent supervision.

Decision
• The House of Lords held that the Home Office was liable for the damages incurred by the claimant.
• It was held that the Home Office did owe a duty of care to the claimant, as it was reasonably foreseeable that the young offenders could cause damage to the yachts if they were not adequately caused was also deemed to be a natural and probable consequence of the negligent supervision.

Key passage(s)
• '[W]hen a new point arises one should ask oneself not whether the alleged liability is covered by authority but whether recognised principles apply to the case. ... The crucial question in the present case is, in my opinion not whether the appellant's officers' intervention can be brought under one or other of the words 'escaped or been let loose' but whether they created a source of danger which they ought to have known might, unless controlled, cause damage to the respondents' property.' (Lord Reid)
• 'In cases where the damage is brought about by the deliberate act of a third party, it is relevant in determining whether a duty of care existed to consider the likelihood of such an intervening act: if the whole course of events is likely, the existence of a duty of care may be established but not otherwise.' (Lord Morris)
• 'Once it is established that the man who creates a source of danger is potentially liable to anyone, whether he be an adult or a child or a madman or a criminal, - who can reasonably be anticipated to be exposed to that risk, it might logically be thought that the creator of the danger should also be liable to anyone who acts just as foreseeably in response to the temptation which the danger presents.' (Lord Diplock)

R v Dudley and Stephens (1884) 14 QBD 273 DC
cases.summary:
Facts
• In 1884, four men, including Thomas Dudley and Edwin Stephens, were stranded at sea for 20 days after their yacht sank.
• They were without food or water for several days and became delirious.
• In their desperation, Dudley and Stephens killed and ate the cabin boy, Richard Parker, who was 17 years old.
• Upon their rescue, they were charged with murder.

Issues
• The main issue was whether the men were guilty of murder or if they could rely on the defence of necessity.
• The defence argued that they had acted out of necessity to save their own lives, and that the boy would have died anyway.
• The prosecution argued that the men had committed murder and that there was no defence for their actions.

Decision
• The court held that the men were guilty of murder and rejected the defence of necessity.
• The judges stated that there was no absolute rule that the preservation of a person's own life justified taking the life of an innocent person.
• The court emphasized the importance of the sanctity of human life and the need to maintain social order, even in extreme circumstances.

Key passage(s)
• 'It is not necessary to consider whether the killing of the boy was or was not a murder if the killing was a necessity, because that necessity did not arise. The prisoners before killing the boy had not reduced themselves to the last extremity of hunger, thirst, and exhaustion.' (Lord Coleridge CJ)
• 'I cannot see any sufficient reason for extending the rule which permits acts of self-defence to cases such as this, and I think that the plea of necessity cannot be supported.' (Lord Huddleston)
• 'In my opinion the whole law on the subject of necessity is extremely unsatisfactory. It is founded partly on mistaken analogies, partly on a too literal and narrow reading of decided cases.' (Lord Blackburn)
